rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:1
rsbNotes.text: 92:1 Most High. This title is similar to one commonly given to Baal in Canaanite religious texts. Applying it to the God of Israel is a kind of taunt directed toward anyone tempted to worship Baal (83:18).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:2
rsbNotes.text: 92:2 your steadfast love . . . your faithfulness. In His covenant with His people, God pledges Himself to love them faithfully. He is the author of the terms of the covenant binding Him and His people together (136:1 and note).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:4
rsbNotes.text: 92:4 your work . . . the works of your hands. The psalmist concentrates on God’s acts in time and space. God is not out of touch with created reality, but works through such reality to demonstrate His love for His people.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:5
rsbNotes.text: 92:5 How great . . . thoughts are very deep. God’s acts and thoughts overwhelm us as we contemplate them. They draw us on to reverent fascination and humble devotion that exceeds our poor grasp.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:7
rsbNotes.text: 92:7 the wicked sprout like grass. The psalmist does not deny that the wicked appear to prosper in this world.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:9
rsbNotes.text: 92:9 your enemies shall perish. As the psalmist meditates on the greatness and justice of God, he comes to the sure conclusion that the wicked will be destroyed.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:10
rsbNotes.text: 92:10 you have exalted my horn. The horn of an animal is used in the Bible as a symbol of power. The wild ox raises its horn with pride and confidence. See 75:4; 89:17; 132:17; 148:14 and notes.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:12
rsbNotes.text: 92:12 like the palm tree . . . like a cedar. A strong contrast is drawn between the flourishing of the righteous and the destruction of the wicked (v. 7). The wicked are like fragile grass, whereas the righteous are strong, vital, and productive trees. A similar type of contrast is found in Ps. 1.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 92:13
rsbNotes.text: 92:13 planted in the house of the Lord. The source of the vitality of the righteous is not themselves, but God.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 93
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 93 This short poem stands at the head of a group of psalms that praise God as King (93; 95–100). Comparison may also be made with Ps. 24 and 46.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 93:1
rsbNotes.text:
93:1 The Lord reigns. This phrase and its slight variants may be found throughout this section of the Psalter (Ps. 96:10; 97:1; 98:6; 99:1). God is King, with omnipotent power and sovereign control over the world. See “God Reigns: Divine Sovereignty” at Dan. 4:34.

the world is established. This word of assurance is based on the fact that the King has created and maintains the world. The forces of evil, disorder, and chaos (vv. 3, 4) will not overwhelm the world.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 93:2
rsbNotes.text: 93:2 you are from everlasting. God has no beginning; He is uncreated. This conception of the eternal kingship of God stands in stark contrast with the theology of Mesopotamia and Canaan. In these neighboring regions, the power of the gods varied according to changes in the political arena.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 93:3
rsbNotes.text: 93:3 The floods. An ancient symbol of the forces of chaos and evil. See notes 18:4, 15.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 93:5
rsbNotes.text: 93:5 Your decrees. The stability and order that exists because of God’s eternal kingship is shared with humanity through the revealed law.
